title: JOIN Terminology Inner Outer Semi Anti...
Let’s say we have two tables (A and B) and some of their rows match (relative to the given JOIN condition, whatever it may be in the particular case):

inline_content.Text: Let’s say we have two tables (A and B) and some of their rows match (relative to the given JOIN condition, whatever it may be in the particular case):

title: We can use various join types to include or exclude matching or non-matching rows from either side, and correctly name the join by picking the corresponding terms from the diagram above.

inline_content.Text: We can use various join types to include or exclude matching or non-matching rows from either side, and correctly name the join by picking the corresponding terms from the diagram above.

title: The examples below use the following test data:

inline_content.Text: The examples below use the following test data:

title: Inner Join
Combines left and right rows that match.

inline_content.Text: Combines left and right rows that match.

title:
SELECT * FROM A JOIN B ON X = Y;

X      Y
------ -----
Lisa   Lisa
Marco  Marco
Phil   Phil

content_resolved.code:
SELECT * FROM A JOIN B ON X = Y;

X      Y
------ -----
Lisa   Lisa
Marco  Marco
Phil   Phil

title: Left Outer Join
Sometimes abbreviated to “left join”. Combines left and right rows that match, and includes non-matching left rows.

inline_content.Text: Sometimes abbreviated to “left join”. Combines left and right rows that match, and includes non-matching left rows.

title:
SELECT * FROM A LEFT JOIN B ON X = Y;

X      Y
-----  -----
Amy    NULL
John   NULL
Lisa   Lisa
Marco  Marco
Phil   Phil

content_resolved.code:
SELECT * FROM A LEFT JOIN B ON X = Y;

X      Y
-----  -----
Amy    NULL
John   NULL
Lisa   Lisa
Marco  Marco
Phil   Phil

title: Right Outer Join
Sometimes abbreviated to “right join”. Combines left and right rows that match, and includes non-matching right rows.

inline_content.Text: Sometimes abbreviated to “right join”. Combines left and right rows that match, and includes non-matching right rows.

title:
SELECT * FROM A RIGHT JOIN B ON X = Y;

X      Y
-----  -------
Lisa   Lisa
Marco  Marco
Phil   Phil
NULL   Tim
NULL   Vincent

content_resolved.code:
SELECT * FROM A RIGHT JOIN B ON X = Y;

X      Y
-----  -------
Lisa   Lisa
Marco  Marco
Phil   Phil
NULL   Tim
NULL   Vincent

title: Full Outer Join
Sometimes abbreviated to “full join”. Union of left and right outer join.

inline_content.Text: Sometimes abbreviated to “full join”. Union of left and right outer join.

title:
SELECT * FROM A FULL JOIN B ON X = Y;

X      Y
-----  -------
Amy    NULL
John   NULL
Lisa   Lisa
Marco  Marco
Phil   Phil
NULL   Tim
NULL   Vincent

content_resolved.code:
SELECT * FROM A FULL JOIN B ON X = Y;

X      Y
-----  -------
Amy    NULL
John   NULL
Lisa   Lisa
Marco  Marco
Phil   Phil
NULL   Tim
NULL   Vincent

title: Left Semi Join
Includes left rows that match right rows.

inline_content.Text: Includes left rows that match right rows.

title:
SELECT * FROM A WHERE X IN (SELECT Y FROM B);

X
-----
Lisa
Marco
Phil

content_resolved.code:
SELECT * FROM A WHERE X IN (SELECT Y FROM B);

X
-----
Lisa
Marco
Phil

title: Right Semi Join
Includes right rows that match left rows.

inline_content.Text: Includes right rows that match left rows.

title:
SELECT * FROM B WHERE Y IN (SELECT X FROM A);

Y
-----
Lisa
Marco
Phil

content_resolved.code:
SELECT * FROM B WHERE Y IN (SELECT X FROM A);

Y
-----
Lisa
Marco
Phil

title: As you can see, there is no dedicated IN syntax for left vs. right semi join - we achieve the effect simply by switching the table positions within SQL text.

inline_content.Text: As you can see, there is no dedicated IN syntax for left vs. right semi join - we achieve the effect simply by switching the table positions within SQL text.

title: Left Anti Semi Join
Includes left rows that do
not
b
match right rows.

SELECT * FROM A WHERE X NOT IN (SELECT Y FROM B);

X
----
Amy
John

content_resolved.code:
SELECT * FROM A WHERE X NOT IN (SELECT Y FROM B);

X
----
Amy
John

title: WARNING:
b
Be careful if you happen to be using NOT IN on a NULL-able column! More details
here
a
http://stackoverflow.com/a/132402/533120

inline_content.Text: Be careful if you happen to be using NOT IN on a NULL-able column! More details

title: Right Anti Semi Join
Includes right rows that do
not
b
match left rows.

SELECT * FROM B WHERE Y NOT IN (SELECT X FROM A);

Y
-------
Tim
Vincent

content_resolved.code:
SELECT * FROM B WHERE Y NOT IN (SELECT X FROM A);

Y
-------
Tim
Vincent

title: As you can see, there is no dedicated NOT IN syntax for left vs. right anti semi join - we achieve the effect simply by switching the table positions within SQL text.

inline_content.Text: As you can see, there is no dedicated NOT IN syntax for left vs. right anti semi join - we achieve the effect simply by switching the table positions within SQL text.

title: Cross Join
A Cartesian product of all left with all right rows.

inline_content.Text: A Cartesian product of all left with all right rows.

title:
SELECT * FROM A CROSS JOIN B;

X      Y
-----  -------
Amy    Lisa
John   Lisa
Lisa   Lisa
Marco  Lisa
Phil   Lisa
Amy    Marco
John   Marco
Lisa   Marco
Marco  Marco
Phil   Marco
Amy    Phil
John   Phil
Lisa   Phil
Marco  Phil
Phil   Phil
Amy    Tim
John   Tim
Lisa   Tim
Marco  Tim
Phil   Tim
Amy    Vincent
John   Vincent
Lisa   Vincent
Marco  Vincent
Phil   Vincent

content_resolved.code:
SELECT * FROM A CROSS JOIN B;

X      Y
-----  -------
Amy    Lisa
John   Lisa
Lisa   Lisa
Marco  Lisa
Phil   Lisa
Amy    Marco
John   Marco
Lisa   Marco
Marco  Marco
Phil   Marco
Amy    Phil
John   Phil
Lisa   Phil
Marco  Phil
Phil   Phil
Amy    Tim
John   Tim
Lisa   Tim
Marco  Tim
Phil   Tim
Amy    Vincent
John   Vincent
Lisa   Vincent
Marco  Vincent
Phil   Vincent

title: Cross join is equivalent to an inner join with join condition which always matches, so the following query would have returned the same result:

inline_content.Text: Cross join is equivalent to an inner join with join condition which always matches, so the following query would have returned the same result:

title: SELECT * FROM A JOIN B ON 1 = 1;

content_resolved.code: SELECT * FROM A JOIN B ON 1 = 1;

title: Self-Join
This simply denotes a table joining with itself. A self-join can be any of the join types discussed above. For example, this is a an inner self-join:

inline_content.Text: This simply denotes a table joining with itself. A self-join can be any of the join types discussed above. For example, this is a an inner self-join:

title:
SELECT * FROM A A1 JOIN A A2 ON LEN(A1.X) < LEN(A2.X);

X     X
----  -----
Amy   John
Amy   Lisa
Amy   Marco
John  Marco
Lisa  Marco
Phil  Marco
Amy   Phil

content_resolved.code:
SELECT * FROM A A1 JOIN A A2 ON LEN(A1.X) < LEN(A2.X);

X     X
----  -----
Amy   John
Amy   Lisa
Amy   Marco
John  Marco
Lisa  Marco
Phil  Marco
Amy   Phil
